pli-tv-pvr7:28.1: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of condemnation against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.2: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.3: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of demotion against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.4: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.6: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of banishing him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.7: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.9: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of reconciliation against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.10: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.12: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of ejecting him for not recognizing an offense:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.13: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.15: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of ejecting him for not making amends for an offense:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.16: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.18: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of ejecting him for not giving up a bad view:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.19: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.1: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, plan a strong action against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.2: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.3: When a monk has three qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.4: he is shameless, ignorant, and not a regular monk.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.5: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.6: he has failed in the higher morality; he has failed in conduct; he has failed in view.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.7: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.8: his bodily conduct is frivolous; his verbal conduct is frivolous; his bodily and verbal conduct are frivolous.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.9: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.10: he is improperly behaved by body; he is improperly behaved by speech; he is improperly behaved by body and speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.11: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.12: his bodily conduct is harmful; his verbal conduct is harmful; his bodily and verbal conduct are harmful.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.13: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.14: he has wrong livelihood by body; he has wrong livelihood by speech; he has wrong livelihood by body and speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.15: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.16: if, after committing an offense and having a legal procedure done against him, he: (1) gives the full ordination, (2) gives formal support, (3) has a novice monk attend on him.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.17: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.18: he commits the same offense for which the Sangha did the legal procedure against him; he commits an offense similar to the one for which the Sangha did the legal procedure against him; he commits an offense worse than the one for which the Sangha did the legal procedure against him.
pli-tv-pvr7:29.19: When a monk has three other qualities a legal procedure may be done against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:29.20: he disparages the Buddha; he disparages the Teaching; he disparages the Sangha.

pli-tv-pvr7:33.1: There are three kinds of persons bound for a hell:

pli-tv-pvr7:33.13: for the restraint of bad people; for the ease of good monks, stopping those with bad desires from creating a faction and then splitting the Sangha; and out of compassion for families.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.1: If he is possessed of five qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.3: If he is possessed of five qualities an expert on Discipline is reckoned as clever:

pli-tv-pvr7:66.1: A monk who is possessed of five qualities should not live independently:

pli-tv-pvr7:66.3: A monk who is possessed of five qualities may live independently:

pli-tv-pvr7:67.1: Five perils for one of unpleasing (actions):
pli-tv-pvr7:67.2: the self upbraids the self, and the wise, having adjudicated, blame him, an evil Rumour spreads abroad (about him), he does his time while he is confused, at the breaking up of the body after dying he arises in a sorrowful way, a bad bourn, the Downfall, Niraya.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.3: Five advantages for one of pleasing (actions):
pli-tv-pvr7:67.4: the self does not upbraid the self, and the wise, having adjudicated, praise him, a lovely rumour spreads abroad (about him), he does his time while he is unconfused, at the breaking up of the body after dying he arises in a good bourn, a heaven world.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.5: And five further perils for one of unpleasing (actions):
pli-tv-pvr7:67.6: non-believers are not pleased, there is wavering among some believers, the Teacher’s instruction is not carried out, people coming after fall into the way of wrong views, his mind is not pleased.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.7: Five advantages for one of pleasing (actions):
pli-tv-pvr7:67.8: non-believers are pleased, there is increase of believers, the Teacher’s instruction is carried out, people coming after do not fall into the way of wrong views, his mind is pleased.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.9: Five perils for one who is dependent on families:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.10: he falls into (the offence of) walking for alms without having asked for permission, he falls into (the offence of) sitting down in private, he falls into (the offence of sitting down) on a concealed seat, he falls into (the offence of) teaching _Dhamma_ to women in more than five or six sentences, and he lives full of aspirations after sense-pleasures.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.11: Five perils for a monk who is dependent on families:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.12: living in too much association with families there is a constant seeing of the women-folk, if there is seeing there is contact, if there is contact there is intimacy, if there is intimacy there is desire, if his mind (is affected by) desire this may be expected for the monk: either he will fare the Brahma-faring dissatisfied or he will fall into some defiling offence or, disavowing the training, he will revert to the secular life.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.2: propagation from roots … from stems … from joints … from cuttings, and fifthly propagation from seeds.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.3: Fruit that is in five ways allowable to recluses may be made use of:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.4: if it is damaged by fire, damaged by a knife, damaged by (one’s) nail, if it is seedless, and the fifth is if the seeds have been discharged.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.6: having recited the provenance, the rest may be announced as though it had been heard (already): this is the first purification;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.7: having recited the provenance, having recited the four offences involving Defeat, the rest may be announced as though it had been heard (already): this is the second purification;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.8: having recited the provenance, having recited the four offences involving Defeat, having recited the thirteen offences entailing a Formal Meeting of the Order, the rest may be announced as though it had been heard (already): this is the third purification;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.9: having recited the provenance … offences involving Defeat … entailing a Formal Meeting of the Order, having recited the two Undetermined Offences, the rest may be announced as though it had been heard (already): this is the fourth purification;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.10: recital in full is the fifth.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.12: recital of the rules, Observance when there is entire purity, Observance when there is determination, Invitation, and the fifth is Observance with “being all together”.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.13: Five advantages for an expert in Discipline:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.14: his own body of moral habit is well guarded, well protected; he is a shelter for those who are affected by scruples; confidently he lives in the midst of an Order; with _Dhamma_ he restrains adversaries (of the Teaching) from one who is well restrained; he is one who practises for the stability of True _Dhamma_.

pli-tv-pvr7:97.1: A monk who is possessed of seven qualities is an expert on Discipline:
pli-tv-pvr7:97.2: if he knows what is an offence, if he knows what is not an offence; if he knows what is a slight offence, if he knows what is a serious offence; if, possessed of moral habit, he lives controlled by the control of the _Pātimokkha_; if, possessed of right conduct and resort, seeing danger in the slightest faults, he, undertaking them, trains himself in the rules of training; if he is one who acquires at will, without trouble, without difficulty, the four meditations that are of the purest mentality—abidings in ease here and now; and if, by the destruction of the cankers, he, having realized here and now by his own super-knowledge the freedom of mind and the freedom through wisdom that are cankerless, enters and abides therein.
